name: Reykjanesviti - Iceland's Oldest Lighthouse
description: Reykjanesviti represents Iceland's oldest lighthouse marking critical navigation point at Reykjanes Peninsula's southwestern tip where Atlantic shipping approaching Iceland encounters first landfall requiring beacon guidance preventing shipwrecks on treacherous volcanic coastline—location at Reykjanestá ('smoke point') reflects extreme geothermal activity surrounding lighthouse where steaming vents, volcanic landscapes, and seismic instability create dramatic setting demonstrating Iceland's geological dynamism at junction where North American and Eurasian tectonic plates diverge. The first lighthouse constructed 1878 on nearby Valahnúkur represented Iceland's initial permanent navigation aid responding to increasing maritime traffic as Iceland integrated into North Atlantic shipping networks during late 19th century industrialization, though original structure's vulnerability to earthquakes and ocean erosion became apparent when geological activity and wave action damaged foundation threatening collapse necessitating replacement within three decades demonstrating challenges maintaining infrastructure in seismically active coastal environment. The current lighthouse built 1907-1908 on more stable Bæjarfell hill replaced compromised original structure after deliberate explosion demolished predecessor April 16.
address: Reykjanesviti, Reykjanestá, Reykjanes Peninsula, Southwest Iceland
